Alpha Epsilon Pi was founded to provide opportunities for the Jewish college man seeking the best possible college and fraternity experience. We have maintained the integrity of our purpose by strengthening our ties to the Jewish community and serving as a link between high school and career.

Our heritage stems from one source: young Jewish men banding together in allegiance. The role of Alpha Epsilon Pi has expanded since its inception in 1913. Initially, the Jewish fraternity served as a brotherhood of young men who came from similar religious backgrounds and who had experienced the same prejudices against their religious beliefs. Alpha Epsilon Pi soon broadened its role to include serving as the living quarters for some of its members. The fraternity became a home away from home, providing the same stabilizing and guiding values that students previously gained from their families. Armed with these values, Alpha Epsilon Pi faced changing conditions on the college campus and survived. Today, Jewish students search out Alpha Epsilon Pi because it is a Jewish Fraternity. In the fraternity’s 100-year history, over 93,000 men have worn the badge of Alpha Epsilon Pi and each year, over 2,500 undergraduates perform the Ritual of Initiation, which remains the same ritual adopted decades ago.

Perhaps of greater importance, Alpha Epsilon Pi develops leadership for the future of the American Jewish community. Tomorrow’s Jewish leaders are in our chapters today. These are the young men who must be counted upon to support Jewish causes and to prepare to be one of tomorrow’s Jewish leaders, so that they may aid themselves, their family, their community, and their people. Those students who enter the mainstream of non-Jewish life on the campus are far more likely to assimilate and to forsake their heritage. Working together with the Foundation for Jewish Campus Life/International Hillel, Alpha Epsilon Pi can play a vital role in helping reverse the growing trend among our young people to abandon Judaism at this critical time.

Throughout our history, the fraternity setting has served as a “learning laboratory”, a testing ground for young men who later become leaders in business, education, government, religion, and science. A goal of our fraternity is to help each student to develop character, to learn responsibility, and to develop a proper set of values through living together in brotherhood. Alpha Epsilon Pi prepares young men for their role in life as responsible citizens.

Therefore, our basic purpose is to provide the opportunity for a Jewish man to be able to join a Jewish organization whose purpose is not specifically religious, but rather social and cultural in nature. Alpha Epsilon Pi is a Jewish fraternity, though non-discriminatory and open to all who are willing to espouse its purpose and values.

Alpha Gamma Delta, fraternity for women, was founded at Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York on May 30, 1904. Alpha Gamma Delta was officially founded at the home of Dr. Wellesley Perry Coddington, a professor at Syracuse University. Dr. Coddington graduated from Wesleyan University in 1860 and was a member of Eclectic Fraternity, Phi Nu Theta and Phi Beta Kappa.  He became one of the first five members of Syracuse University’s faculty in 1871 and was instrumental in the early development of Alpha Gamma Delta.

 

From 1900-1905, enrollment at Syracuse doubled and this led Dr. Coddington to discuss the need for more organizations with Marguerite Shepard, Because Marguerite was ending her junior year and would soon be graduating, she shared Dr. Coddington’s idea with her younger sister, Estelle, a member of the class of 1908.  Estelle saw the chance to make college friendships deeper and discussed the possibility with her close friend, Georgia Dickover.  These three women embraced the idea and made a list of other women to consider for membership.  With Marguerite, Estelle and Georgia’s approval, Dr. Coddington spoke with Jennie Titus, a member of his ethics class about the opportunity.  She joined the group at their second meeting and became an energetic and eager worker.

 

On May 30, 1904, eleven pioneering women came together to form Alpha Gamma Delta.  Since the founding, collegiate chapters have been installed at 181 colleges and universities across North America and more than 145,000 women have become Alpha Gam sisters. Guided by our Purpose, Alpha Gamma Deltas are impacting our communities and contributing to the world's work.

With the chartering of Tau chapter at the University of Toronto in 1919, Alpha Gamma Delta became an International Women’s Fraternity. Furthermore, Alpha Gamma Delta was admitted into the National Panhellenic Conference in 1909.

Ascend is the largest, non-profit Pan-Asian organization for business professionals in North America. Established in 2005, Ascend has grown to serve professionals and corporations across various professions and across multiple industries.

Ascend reaches 60,000 people with 30 student chapters and 17 professional chapters located in both the United States and Canada around major business hubs and educational institutions. We offer robust professional development and career enhancement programs designed to cultivate Pan-Asian talent. In addition, the National Association of Asian MBAs (NAAMBA), Ascend’s national organization for MBA professionals and students, fosters Competent, Committed, Competitive, and Collaborative global MBA leaders to fulfill diverse talent pipelines. Ascend Foundation's research provides the basis to the development of our leadership and development programs.

Our Vision

Enhance the presence and influence of current and future Pan-Asian business leaders and serve as a collective voice for Pan-Asian business communities.

Our Mission

Be the premier professional organization dedicated to enabling its members, corporate partners and the professional Pan-Asian community to leverage the leadership and global business potential of Pan-Asian professionals worldwide.

Objectives 

  • Connect Pan-Asian leaders across industries through a network of seasoned professionals and emerging leaders
  • Enable young professionals and emerging leaders to pursue their dreams and achieve new professional heights
  • Assist our partners and sponsors to achieve their business growth through world-class diversity and inclusion practices

 

Our Membership

Membership is open to individuals of all ethnicities and business backgrounds. The majority of our members come from fields where there is a high concentration of Pan-Asians – accounting, financial services, technology, engineering, professional services, and others in business, government, and academia.

Our Community

Pan-Asians have cultural origins from more than 32 ethnic groups. Of those, six major groups account for more than 95 percent of the Pan-Asians in the U.S.: Asian Indian, Chinese, Filipino, Japanese, Korean and Vietnamese. The role that they play in the global marketplace continues to grow with the economic growth of Asia, especially China, India and Southeast Asia. Pan-Asian professionals represent a pipeline of strong talent for companies.

 

Today, Pan-Asians are high contributors to U.S. and global businesses: 

  • The Pan-Asian population is expected to triple to 40 million in the next 40 years
  • The Pan-Asian workforce is highly-educated, technically skilled and affluent with tremendous leadership potential
  • Pan-Asian corporations are setting up operations in the U.S. and represent the fastest growing market

The Baja SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers) competition challenges engineering students to design, manufacture, test, and race an off road vehicle. Each competition consists of multiple dynamic events and an off-road race. There are three competitions held each year, in which 100 teams from around the world must prove that their car is safe, well-engineered, cost-effective, fast, maneuverable, and able to endure an off-road environment. In addition to the performance of the car, the team is judged on two detailed reports: one for design and one for cost.

The cars are put to the test with dynamic events, where teams compete in acceleration, hill climbing, maneuverability, and more. Each competition ends with a 4-hour endurance race, including obstacles such as creeks, jumps, hairpin turns, and other difficult terrain and manmade obstacles. When cars break down, teams are expected to use their problem solving skills to perform onsite repairs and get their car back in the race.

For more information visit: www.lehighbaja.com

Read more about how you can help Bridges to Prosperity, why bridges are life-improving catalysts in rural communities all over the world, and about our partnerships with the private sector, universities and civic organizations.

University Program

Bridges to Prosperity (B2P) engages university students from around the world, providing opportunities to use their academic training on a real-life, practical project. Many students are able to fulfill their senior design or service-learning requirements by working with B2P.

Once you start a University Chapter at your school, there are a number of ways to be involved in a B2P bridge project. The core of our University Program consists of Chapter Projects, where students manage entire projects from start to finish while taking advantage of B2P’s technical resources and one-on-one support from technical mentors. Program Projects, in which student teams are assigned to a bridge project and receive direct support from B2P field staff, serve as a training mechanism to empower students to complete Chapter Projects in subsequent years. University Chapters who elect not to build a bridge have the option of traveling on inspection trips for completed B2P bridges and exploring topics relevant to our work through research and development, including non-technical projects.

On a national level at college campuses across the United States (44 in total), students get together and bake challah bread, sell this bread to students, and donate the proceeds: 50% to Mazon and the other 50% to a charity of their choice. Since the club has started, they have raised over $200,000 for non-governmental organizations and the Sudan REleif FinMazon

There is a $5 suggested donation for each loaf of challah, but people can feel free to donate more or less.

The Chaplain's Office is located in The Dialogue Center at 661 Taylor Street.

The office is open Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

The Rev. Dr. Lloyd Steffen is the University Chaplain. He is an ordained Protestant minister (United Church of Christ), a tenured Professor of Religion Studies who teaches religion and ethics in the Department of Religion Studies, and he is also Director of the Dialogue Center and the Lehigh Prison Project.

Appointed in August 2017, Dr. Walead Mosaad is the University's first Director of Muslim Student Life.

Rabbi Steven P. Nathan is serving as the Interim Director of Jewish Student Life.

Terri Ball-Nicholas is the Chaplain's Office Coordinator and Packer Church Wedding Coordinator.  Appointments with the Chaplain may be scheduled by calling 610-758-3877.

The Center for Dialogue, Ethics and Spirituality serves the educational mission of Lehigh University by providing space and resources designed to enhance the “ethical and spiritual development” of those who live and work at Lehigh—students, faculty and staff. Recognizing that people of good will disagree with one another on topics involving ethical analysis, spirituality and religious interpretation, the Center seeks to promote the values of open and free inquiry, engaged dialogue, and respect for persons regardless of race, ethnicity, religion, gender identity or sexual orientation. In support of Lehigh University’s stated commitment to “harmonious cultural diversity” and the expressed hope that “all members of the Lehigh community might develop as effective and enlightened citizens,” the Center is open to the entire campus to serve both academic and co-curricular needs. The Center is directed by the Office of the University Chaplain.

Dedicated to the purpose of maintaining and promoting the status of civil engineering as an ideal profession, Chi-Epsilon was organized to recognize the characteristics of the individual civil engineer deemed to be fundamental to the successful pursuit of an engineering career, and to aid in the development of those characteristics in the civil engineering student. Engineering, the application of scientific principles to the practical needs of society, is assuming a constantly increasing responsibility for the well-being of all people, and thus calling for competence of the highest order. This responsibility can be discharged only by a professional group whose members are possessed of a good basic technical ability, intelligence, moral integrity, and effective social poise in their relationship with the larger community of which they are part. To contribute to the improvement of the profession, Chi Epsilon fosters the development and exercise of sound traits of character and technical ability among civil engineers, and its members, by precept and example, toward an ever higher standard of professional service.

The Lehigh University Choir is a very active force on campus. The 60 mixed voices of the Choir are auditioned at the beginning of the academic year, and are drawn from all majors of the University.

 

The choral tradition of Lehigh University dates back to the 1880′s, when a Mandolin and Singing Club was formed by the undergraduates. Since that time, there has been an unbroken growth of singing at Lehigh. Dr. Steven Sametz is the fifth director of choral activities in Lehigh’s century of choral singing, having joined the faculty in 1979.

 

The Choir performs frequently with orchestra, including the major works of J.S. Bach (the B-minor Mass, Magnificat, and a staged version of the Matthauspassion with Baroque orchestra) and has been featured in concert with the Grammy-Award winning ensemble, Chanticleer. The Choir has been heard on National Public Radio, performing works from the medieval to modern eras, with many new works written specifically for them. They tour internationally, with recent tours to Hawaii, Costa Rica, China, Germany, and the Czech Republic. Past tours include Moscow, St. Petersburg, and Berlin; California; the Virgin Islands; Austria and Hungary; France; and East Asia.

Lehigh University Class Officer- Program Overview

What is the Class Officer (CO) Program?

The CO Program is a group of elected students that represent their class and serve as a liaison between the Lehigh Fund and the student body. Class officers provide strong, consistent representation of the class to students, faculty, staff, alumni and administration and are tasked with unifying their class through the promotion of philanthropy.

The class officer program at Lehigh is unique as it does not play the role of student government. Here at Lehigh, that role is reserved for Lehigh’s Student Senate. The class officer program is a necessity for the institution as many of the campus programs, student organizations, and opportunities here at Lehigh would not exist without annual giving. The class officer program highlights philanthropy because of its connection to the Lehigh Fund.

 What is the Lehigh Fund?

The Lehigh Fund is an annual giving program whose purpose is to raise funds to support Lehigh University’s highest priorities. Each year the Lehigh Fund raises over $16 million that provides immediate support for student life programs, the academic experience, and financial aid. The Lehigh Fund is the parent organization to the Class Officer Program and supports it through providing a staff advisor, budget, and resources which allow the class officers to have a strong presence on campus.

 The Bigger Picture – Lehigh Fund, Class Officers, and Lehigh University

At Lehigh you be exposed to endless opportunities. From getting involved on campus, to studying with top-notch professors, to watching or participating in varsity athletics, or joining your fellow brothers and sisters in Greek life – Lehigh is a place that allows you to discover your passions and grow as a student and global citizen. Much of what you experience here at Lehigh would not be possible without the financial support of alumni, students, parents, faculty, and friends who have generously supported Lehigh through giving to the annual fund. The class officer program is a unique opportunity for you to strengthen and support the place that will undoubtedly change your life.

Hi Dems! Our goal as a club is to promote political awareness and encourage intellectual discussions and debates about current issues. We focus on the challenges our country faces and how the Democratic Party platform addresses those issues. To promote political awareness we work to register all students to vote, both partisan and non-partisan. We also do what we can to support the Democratic Party’s candidates from the local to national campaigns. Feel free to reach out to our email with any questions or important events or issues you think we should be aware of! We welcome everyone who wants to explore more about politics and meet like-minded students.

The College Republicans is an organization dedicated to informing and engaging our members with regard to current events, policy, and politics. At a time in this country when politics has become extremely partisan, getting students involved in the political discourse of this country is of paramount importance. By sparking conversations and thoughts about some of the divisive issues facing our country today, we can foster a more open University environment and bring new ideas to the surface of discussion. We offer opportunities for student involvement by learning about political campaigns and their operations firsthand, arranging visits from politicians and political speakers, attending conservative conferences, and organizing debates that bring current political issues into focus.
Colleges Against Cancer works with the American Cancer Society through four main aspects - advocacy, mission, survivorship and Relay For Life.

The Garden Club focuses on three pillars of Permaculture, which are Earth Care, People Care, and Fair Share. Permaculture emphasizes the "edge", or where two different things meet, so our focus is primarily on community building in the Southside area. We have embodied each of our pillars in this light. For earth care, we take care of 4 community gardens bordering the Southside. For people care, we have an educational program with Boys & Girls Club of Bethlehem since the summer, and we are looking forward to beginning an after-school program with Broughal Middle School. During these programs, we have had the children paint bricks to label our vegetables, made zucchini pizza and pickled our own cucumbers, taught them about composting and even had them compost with us in our garden. Finally, for fair share, the majority of our yields are donated to New Bethany food pantry to help those in the community without ready access to fresh produce. We are already in talks with Lehigh's Space Committee and hope to establish an educational Permaculture garden on campus so that Lehigh students can learn about its principles as well. We operate on the philosophy that "You don't have to leave your community to live in a better one". We find that our mission is unique in that we are encouraging community building around the garden so that Southside residents and Lehigh Students alike can have a personal stake in their community as well as learn more about growing their own food, which is a significant aspect of a more sustainable lifestyle.

Our mission in the Community Service Office is to provide students, faculty and staff of Lehigh University a readily accessible doorway through which they can explore the rewards and benefits of providing service to the community.

The mission of CIE Club is to advocate for a cross cultural and cross disciplinary approach to systems, ideas and practices in education to improve the lives of children and adults. The club will support efforts locally, nationally and globally.

The cultural richness and pluralism of the Lehigh student community thrives in its student clubs and organizations. Within the campus community, there are a host of student organizations whose focus is to educate others through the celebration and promotion of communal solidarity.

These organizations take an active and identifiable role on campus by hosting and participating in cultural heritage month celebrations, community service opportunities, lecture series and academic roundtable discussions, mentoring programs, food and dance festivals, career forums and more! The list on the adjoining page highlights many of Lehigh's student organizations.

CREATE seeks to inspire and push future entrepreneurs and technical enthusiasts towards creating and developing new ideas. The idea for this club came from our drive to start thinking about and molding ideas early in our college careers.
 
CREATE is a newly founded club at Lehigh University. We are looking for innovative thinkers and entrepreneurs who want to take it to the next level to bring their ideas to life.
 
By the end of this semester, we plan on having skill building workshops and hack building sessions. Skill building workshops will allow students to learn new trades such as operating a 3D printer, soldering a circuit, and more. Hacks will be completed on Lehigh campus, and will make landmarks interactive and fun for students.

Through the Baker Institute for Entrepreneurship, Creativity and Innova
tion (one of the fastest growing departments at Lehigh), and this new club, students can start to think about their entrepreneurial goals and how to best integrate those goals into their education. Equally important, this club will serve as a meeting place for people with different perspectives to collaborate and learn about the creative process of developing new ideas and making the technological aspects of those ideas possible.

CREATE will expose students to the world of technical design and production as well as advancing the design reputation of Lehigh University.

Students, Freshman through Senior, would have the opportunity outside of class to supplement the formal engineering curriculum with hands-on experimentation and other learning opportunities in a supervised, structured environment. (This will be especially helpful for freshman and sophomores who normally have limited exposure to designing and building projects).

Entries in commercial product contests (Staples InvestorQuest or Microsoft Imagine Cup).
Entries in Lehigh University and national college business plan and innovation contests.
Prototyping and development of new student-inspired commercial product.
Launching companies around successful product ideas.
Excitement for entrepreneurial ideas and programs around campus (such as iDex).

Dancin' is a dance club open to everyone interested in dance and performance. Dues are collected at the beginning of each semester - they are $40 each semester and cover all classes for each respective semester. Dancin' typically has one recital, as well as other performances throughout the school year, including Fusion, Relay for Life, DanceFest, Spec Spec and the annual International Bazaar. Dancin' is always open to new performance opportunities.

There are currently 4 classes offered:

Wednesday: Jazz, Tap

Thursday: Ballet, Lyrical

All classes take place in a studio on campus and are taught by outside staff.

Members are also free to choreograph their own solos, duets, or pieces in other areas of dance that do not have an actual class meeting during our reserved open time slot in Taylor Gym on Friday early evenings.

Dancin' welcomes anyone interested in dance. Classes are very flexible, and members can take classes without having to perform in the recitals if they do not wish to do so.

lehigh.dancin@gmail.com

Delta Phi has existed at Lehigh since 1884, and is the oldest continuous national fraternity in the country. We're best known for our dance parties, which are packed week after week with Lehigh students. Our largest parties have been our Mardi Gras and Halloween parties. The Delta Phi alumni have been becoming more active every year. Last year alone, they helped organize a rush event to see the New Jersey Nets and gave every departing senior a graduation gift. They are also planning to fully renovate the entire house in the near future. We are very competitive in intramural sports, always making it to the playoffs in soccer, softball, and football. The brothers of Delta Phi are actively involved with all three of Lehigh's major schools, the IFC, and various clubs and sports. We have been placed among the top fraternities academically. We look forward to increasing our brotherhood this year and would like to extend a warm welcome to anyone who would like to visit us.

As a very longstanding, international, all-male college organization, Delta Upsilon has a rich history on Lehigh's campus. This organization is devoted to four main principles: the promotion of friendship, the development of character, the diffusion of liberal culture and the advancement of justice. DU is an organization that prides itself on putting education first, while celebrating the lifelong-brotherly bonds that are formed during the college years. Our members come from a diversity of backgrounds and are involved in a variety of campus activities, clubs and sports. Our fraternity celebrates community service and philanthropic endeavors; namely our annual event, Lassoing Leukemia which helps raise funds for the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. DU's national philanthropy is Global Service Initiative (GSI) which is a coordinated effort to serve those in need, both in other countries and at home.

The Dental Society at Lehigh University is a student-run organization devoted to providing guidance to students interested in pursuing dentistry. The Dental Society seeks to provide opportunities to students that include visits to dental schools, lectures by guest speakers, service trips abroad, as well as other forms of community outreach. The Dental Society is also a great place to gain advice and insight from peers about classes, dentists shadowing, the DAT, dental application process, and other relevant information.

Echoes is the premiere all-female a cappella group on Lehigh’s campus — making its debut in the fall of 2003. We sing many musical styles, including pop, indie, country, hip hop,  jazz, and more. Not only is all our music performed by the students in our group, but every song on our set list is also hand chosen, arranged, and taught by the members, themselves!

We perform on & off campus and like collaborating with Lehigh clubs & other collegiate a cappella groups! Don't be shy to contact us if you're interested in getting us to perform for/with you, or if you may have questions about joining the group! Auditions are held in the beginning of fall semester every year.

Engineers Without Borders - USA (EWB-USA) is a non-profit humanitarian organization established to partner with developing communities worldwide in order to improve their quality of life. This partnership involves the implementation of sustainable infrastructure projects, while involving and training internationally responsible students and professionals from all different backgrounds (you don’t have to be an engineer!) The activities of EWB-USA range from the construction of sustainable systems that developing communities can own and operate without external assistance, to educating and empowering such communities by enhancing local, technical, managerial, and entrepreneurial skills. These projects are initiated by, and completed with, contributions from the host community working with our project teams.

Lehigh University's Chapter of EWB just implemented a water distribution system in Cebadilla, Nicaragua. As we continue to monitor the system, our chapter is looking to other potential projects in the area. Over the course of the next year we will further investigate the need for a bridge project in Cebadilla, Nicaragua and potentially implementing a water distribution system in the Dominican Republic.

LU-EWB also serves to educate and raise awareness both on campus and in the surrounding community of South Bethlehem. This is accomplished through outreach activities and events including a series of in-class projects at Broughal Middle School, awareness campaigns, participation during Green Week at Lehigh, and in general engaging all facets of the community to think about what it means to be sustainable.

The Equestrian Team and Club are organizations that allow riders of all levels to come together to ride for pleasure and to compete. The team competes in the Intercollegiate Horse Show Association, against other schools throughout the school year. The club is a less competitive organization, where members are able to, but not required to, show.

Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) is a unique organization dedicated to encouraging and recognizing excellence in the electrical and computer engineering fields. Founded at the University of Illinois in 1904, HKN consists of students, alumni, and other professionals who have demonstrated exceptional academic and professional accomplishments. Student members are selected on the basis of scholastic standing, character, and leadership. Through a variety of service programs and leadership training, student members develop lifelong skills that earmark them for prominent positions in industry and academia. Members are much better prepared for the post-college world and are especially valuable and attractive to employers. They are recognized as extremely capable, both technically and professionally.

Before we were a club, we had a vision. We envisioned a united community of international students who would provide for each other understanding, comfort, and encouragement to persevere through culture shock and homesickness. We began by making a group chat and organizing potlucks, movie nights, group study sessions, and visits to local events. Friends brought in their friends, and before we knew it, we had over 20 people wanting to join the club before we even considered it to be a “club”! Our current membership consists of students representing: Europe, the Middle East, Latin America, and the United States.

Having a larger membership, we now have the opportunity to create events independently or in collaboration with other clubs on campus. We want to evolve into an organization that educates, fosters respectful debate, and introduces new perspectives. European culture is one of integration, cooperation, and international education. We seek to take these values from home, and bring them to our second home, America. Recognition of our organization would provide us with the resources needed to successfully achieve our vision.

The Food Recovery Network brings together students on college campuses to fight waste and feed people by donating the extra food from their colleges to hungry Americans.

Founded in 2011, FRN has grown to include chapters at more than 191 colleges and universities in 43 states, DC and Puerto Rico that have recovered over 1,400,000 pounds of food.

Each chapter works with on-campus dining halls to bring surplus food to community members in need, while also raising awareness on issues of food waste and hunger in America.

The Lehigh Formula SAE team is an undergraduate engineering club composed of engineering and business students.  Each year the team designs, manufactures, and races a unique racecar in the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) collegiate design competition.

The FSAE competition allows students to experience the complete product development process, from concept through manufacture and assembly.  Students are also introduced to business practices and supplier interactions.

Gaming club is a group dedicated to bringing otherwise unnoticed games to light and teaching others the rules in an attempt to spread a more well rounded healthy entertainment.  We explore many aspects of gaming from role playing to board games to table top games.

German Club is designed to celebrate the German culture and language. Any student interested in these goals is welcome, whether they are enrolled in German class or not. German Club is dedicated to providing every member of the Lehigh community the opportunity to share and learn the German culture, language and history in a fun environment. 

Our largest events of the year are Oktoberfest in the fall and in the spring we have a guest speaker to be determined.

The Global Citizenship Program was started in 2004 through a grant to the university from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and since the grant’s phasing out Lehigh has enthusiastically renewed its funding. Admitting between 20 and 25 students from each class, this 4-year certificate program attracts a wide variety of majors from all three colleges. Many of you may be wondering, “What is global citizenship?” In the term “global citizenship,” both components are equally key. The element of citizenship emphasizes how important it is to exercise and cultivate the virtues of ethical responsibility and compassionate care towards one’s own community. The global element reinforces the point that one of the defining marks of the 21st Century is the fact that our community of reference can no longer be too narrow-minded. It is now clearer than ever that our decisions, though they may appear to only affect those around us, need to be made with a global perspective in mind.

The GU is a coalition of more than 50 student clubs and organizations that promote global awareness and cultural understanding within the Lehigh community and the Lehigh Valley. There are more than 1,000 members from over 40 countries, including one-half of the membership from the United States.

The GU does not replace individual clubs: rather, it allows them a forum to work together. In their willingness to be global in outlook, GU members share a common mission and vision, as well as a space in which to pursue common goals.

Located on the second floor of Coxe Hall, Room 215, the GU hosts numerous events focused on international educational, cultural and social issues.

Annual events include International Week and series of speaker programs. All events at the GU are free and open to the entire Lehigh University community and residents of the region.

The Objectives of the Graduate Student Senate are as follows:

 

1) To serve as the representing body of the Graduate Student community in all matters pertinent to the graduate programs and Graduate Student life at Lehigh University.

2) To encourage communication among Graduate Students.

3) To provide Graduate Students with a forum to discuss issues pertinent to the graduate programs and Graduate Student life at Lehigh University.

4) To acquire information from and disseminate information to the Graduate Student Community.

5) To appoint Graduate Students as representatives of the Graduate Student Senate to serve as Graduate Members of the Graduate and Research Committee, Educational Policy Committee, and other university bodies as the need arises.

6) To approve and present resolutions to the Graduate and Research Committee, Educational Policy Conmmittee, other university bodies, the Provost, President of the University, or the Board of Trustees.

7) To provide the Graduate and Research Committee, Educational Policy Committee, other university bodies, Dean of Graduate Studies, Provost, President of the University, and the Board of Trustees with a forum to discuss issues with Graduate Students, and to prepare position papers when they so request.

8) To maintain a Graduate Student Center.

We raise awareness of environmental issues on Lehigh's campus, pressure administration and students to participate in eco-friendly programs, and promote sustainability on campus and within the community.

We also attend national and state-wide conferences to learn more about the environment, lobby US Senators, protest America's less environmentally friendly activities, and learn how to make our own campus more green.

The purpose and aim of The Lehigh University Club for Gender Equity in Leadership will be to promote the palpable presence of Women in leadership in all aspect of professional and institutional life within the University context and to confront, engage and give space to combatting societal barriers of gendered marginalization. 

The club will hold seminars from alumni that are aimed at developing skills to overcome this barrier, including negotiation, time management and other skills crucial to being a successful leader. Other meetings will be more discussion based about experiences, pop-culture's affect on gender roles and strategies to minimize discrimination.

column4: The vision of Habitat for Humanity is a world where everyone has a decent place to live. As a club, we will help build and repair houses in South Bethlehem and Allentown by connecting with the Lehigh Valley office. The club will also host fundraising events and attend our affiliate's fundraisers to raise money for Lehigh Valley Habitat, Habitat International, and our own future events. Through these events and other projects, we hope to educate Lehigh students and the community about the current housing situation and advocate for change.

Our dedicated, professional staff offers a host of services, including acute care, routine examinations, immunizations, lab services, gynecological examinations and contraceptive counseling. We also have a self-treatment room, as well as wellness resources and relaxation rooms. Please consider us YOUR resource for health information. We welcome the opportunity to serve you.
The Hellenic club's main purpose is to unite the Greek community of Lehigh University and to promote more involvement in the Greek culture and heritage.

The purpose of the Her Campus Lehigh organization is to provide an online hub for Lehigh’s women (and men) by providing content that is both a resource and a source of entertainment, highlighting campus news, events, interesting students, faculty, alumni, campus photos, and fashion and lifestyle content specifically tailored for women at Lehigh. Staff members will gain journalism, marketing,
publicity, and digital media experience, and all students at Lehigh will gain a new and fun online resource through this online publication.

The Lehigh University Hillel Society, is a student-run organization. The Jewish Student Center provides a Jewish home on campus for students to gather to relax, socialize, share a meal, observe Shabbat, and even offers a quiet place to study.

Through the Hillel Society, students have the opportunity to develop new friendships all within a Jewish context. The mission of the Hillel Society is to actively encourage and strengthen the continuity of Jewish values through a combination of religious, Zionist, and cultural programs for Lehigh's Jewish students.

Our program includes a regular series of dinners, holiday observances/celebrations, social events, and educational programming. In addition to the many activities we sponsor throughout the school year, we provide a kosher kitchen, dining room, lounge area, student office, and library. We continually strive to create an atmosphere that is comfortable and welcoming for our students. This effort includes providing quality programming, maintaining our facility, and upgrading our program to accommodate the ever-changing needs of our students.

The HumanitiesCenter provides a physical home as well as intellectual, financial, and organizational support for students, faculty, and staff who wish to come together to participate in humanistic inquiry, understood in the broadest possible terms.  We seek to enrich the work of existing academic departments and programs in the humanities, by stimulating a wide range of activities that move beyond and across disciplines, urging members of the community to consider in the freest and fullest ways what humans are or have been, what humans have produced and are producing.  We seek to break down the division between work and play, between the classroom and the rest of life.   We aim to foster vibrant intellectual inquiry, and to diffuse the energies of such inquiry into the broader culture of the Lehigh campus.  Specifically, we sponsor interdisciplinary curriculum, including team- taught courses.  We choose a theme for each year (Creativity, The Public Intellectual, Waste, Just Globalization, New Bethlehem are examples) – and bring a series of scholars, intellectuals, artists, writers, activists, and visionaries to address related issues.  We also host conferences, cosponsor visiting speakers, support reading groups, and organize a works-in-progress series.  The Humanities Center also hosts a wide range of informal activities to create lively, unstructured humanistic community.

Welcome to Lehigh University’s Indian Students Association! Our mission is to promote awareness of South Asian culture and its rich heritage here at Lehigh.

ISA organizes and participates in several campus-wide events to further this mission. The club teaches Garba (an Indian dance) in order to celebrate the Indian holiday of Navaratri. ISA also partners with India Club to put on the annual Diwali show, celebrating the Indian festival of lights. Members perform cultural dances at events such as FUSION and International Bazaar. The main event of the year is Holi, the Indian festival of colors. Lehigh students gather on the front lawn and throw color to celebrate unity and the arrival of spring. Over 700 students attended the event in 2016! The Diwali Show and Holi have also both received Lehigh’s Student Life Leadership Award for the Best Cultural Program over the past few years!

In addition to campus-wide events, ISA holds numerous social activities for its members. Kappa Alpha Psi, a Greek letter college Fraternity, was founded on January 5th, 1911 at Indiana University, Bloomington Indiana by a group of 10 astute men in spite of many obstacles. The racial climate at Indiana during the early 20th century was quite tenuous, and the founders of the Fraternity sought to create an organization that would never exclude or suggest the exclusion of a man from membership merely because of his color, creed, or national origin.

 

The fraternity’s presence at Lehigh University began on April 18, 1987, when the Lehigh Expansion colony of the Kappa Gamma Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity was established by three undergraduate students - Wayne Bethea, Ron Howard, and Terry Williams. The Omicron Kappa Chapter at Lehigh University was founded on May 18th, 2001 after Brothers of Kappa Alpha Psi were present on campus for over 14 years. Currently, Omicron Kappa is host to the Ursinus College Colony of Kappa Alpha Psi. This chapter boasts a diverse membership of brothers who are involved in many positive initiatives in their communities, and who strive to achieve in everything they do. This is evidenced by the many prestigious accolades bestowed upon the OK chapter.

 

In the 2009-2010 school-year, the Brothers were honored with Gold Chapter status by Lehigh’s Office of Fraternity & Sorority Affairs for the second straight year, and were named Northeastern Province Chapter of the year by the Fraternity’s governing body in 2008-2009. The chapter was also honored by the University by being named Undergraduate Student Organization of the Year at the 2010 Student Life Leadership Awards.

Kappa Delta Sorority was founded in 1897 at State Female Normal School, now Longwood University in Farmville, Va. The thought that over 100 years ago four young women could just sit down and create a sisterhood as enduring as Kappa Delta sometimes defies understanding, but that's exactly what they did.

Today, Kappa Delta is an impressive nationwide organization that reaches far beyond the local chapter. It is a national organization of more than 230,000 initiated members, 157 active collegiate chapters across the country and more than 500 chartered alumnae chapters nationwide. It is led by a National Council, over 100 national volunteers and a professional staff numbering over 40. It is a network of sisters and friends around the world who come from a variety of backgrounds and experiences.

Together, Kappa Deltas impact the lives of members and those in need around the world. Contributions to the Kappa Delta Foundation from alumnae, collegians and friends of Kappa Delta enable the sorority to further its philanthropic efforts, providing support for the sorority’s national philanthropies, numerous local community outreach programs, as well as scholarships and educational opportunities for members. 

We have chosen to become Kappa Deltas because we believe that, in some way, all of us can be better together than each of us can be alone. That is the strength of Kappa Delta nationally

Kappa Kappa Psi is a National Honorary Band Fraternity focusing on service to the college band program.  The Kappa Gamma chapter at Lehigh will be celebrating its 20th anniversary in January 2015.  We have continued to increase and improve our activities throughout the years, particularly with respect to service and fundraising endeavors. This progress has allowed us to develop several new fundraising projects and to expand our service beyond what we have been capable of in recent years.  Our service projects for past years have included cleaning the score library, recataloguing and repackaging marching band music, a marching band loft clean up, volunteering at several USSBA band and colorguard competitions, ushering at Christmas Vespers, hanging posters to advertise musical performances, transporting and organizing sheet music donated to our Wind Ensemble, and giving lessons at the surrounding elementary and middle schools. Additionally, the chapter has offered events open to the entire Lehigh community, most notably our "Acoustics in April" event, which showcases smaller jazz ensembles, a cappella groups, and alternative bands on campus. The chapter looks forward to not only providing service to Lehigh University band programs, but band programs in the surrounding Lehigh Valley area, as well.

Leadership Consultants (LCs) are students who serve as facilitators for various Office of Student Leadership (OSLD) Development programs and workshops.  LCs participate in peer educator facilitator training and receive additional training on various leadership topics to provide fun, interactive, energetic and informative programs for their peers.

Most frequently, the LCs train on the topics of communication, conflict management, goal setting, individual and group decision making, leadership styles, and officer transitions but have the knowledge and ability to create workshops for a range of topics. The LCs consult with clubs and organizations to provide them with personalized workshops to enhance the organization's overall leadership potential and structure.

Leadership Consultant Responsibilities:

  • Participate in debriefing/planning/training meetings each week.
  • Facilitate programs and workshops throughout the semester. The first workshops will be partnered with experienced LCs, so the student can learn the process of consulting with the organization, designing the workshop, creating an agenda, and facilitating the topic.
  • Consult with program requester to assess the needs of the organization. This relationship should be maintained after the workshop to gain feedback and to continue consulting on the group’s dynamics.
  • Participate in ongoing training each semester at retreats and weekly meetings. The meetings are mandatory (with 2 excused absences a semester).
  • Attend fall OSLD retreat in September and spring LC retreat in February
  • Student will undergo semester review of training evaluations and observed trainings. This will be in part from workshop participant surveys and facilitation practice at meetings.

Benefits of Participation:

  • Students will develop transferable, in-depth leadership training and presentation skills
  • Students will develop public speaking and group mediation skills
  • Students will have opportunities to attend National Leadership Conferences sponsored by OSLD (ie. LeaderShape)
  • Students will have the opportunity to work with a diverse group of student leaders on innovative workshops.
  • Students will receive a stipend each semester

Lehigh students who are both drinkers and non-drinkers have voiced a strong interest in attending these types of events and activities and suggested that they are offered on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings between 10 p.m. and 2 a.m.

 

This Lehigh After Dark Activity Fund has been established to provide support for programs that provide undergraduate students with quality social, cultural, intellectual and community development activities that do not focus on alcohol and are open to the entire Lehigh community.

 

Funding will be awarded to new or existing activities held on or off of Lehigh's campus and may be used to cover a variety of activity expenses that include food, security, transportation, facility rental, publicity, or prizes. You may access the FUNDING FORM HERE. (https://goo.gl/forms/P7yt4hVnwg1JOTmH2)

 

Our goal is to support healthy student behavior by expanding the vibrant and exciting social environment at Lehigh.  Providing alcohol-free activities during time periods that are typically problematic for high-risk drinking is one promising prevention strategy.  As a student, you can play an integral role in helping us develop this program by creating new activities, promoting Lehigh After Dark to your peers, and joining the Lehigh After Dark coordinating committee.

NO MORE is a nationwide movement to raise awareness and take action to stop the issues of domestic violence and sexual assault. NO MORE is represented by a teal/blue circle shaped symbol that was designed on the concept of a zero, representing the end goal, that no more people suffer domestic abuse or sexual assault. To achieve this, NO MORE focuses on normalizing conversations surrounding these issues, therefore spreading awareness, eliminating the shame that surrounds these issues, and encouraging bystanders to stop making excuses and to take action. At Lehigh the goal of NO MORE is to start campus wide conversations surrounding these issues. Lehigh Says NO MORE will focus on promoting awareness by hosting several campus wide events throughout the year, holding fundraising events, and by creating our own Lehigh based campaign of public service announcments to get the campus involved in this movement. By being a constant presence and getting everyone talking, we can take these issues out of the dark and finally bring them out into the light.

The Lehigh Undergraduate Mathematics and Statistics Society (LUMSS) is created as a learning environment for everyone, regardless of major, with an interest in Mathematics. This club is created for everyone to share, discuss and help each other understand the mathematical concepts and ideas that are not usually focused nor mentioned in a regular college curriculum.

The Lehigh University Cryptography Club (LUCC) was founded upon the idea that cryptography will continue to play an integral role in society as we further progress into the digital age. Since its inception in 1900 BCE, cryptography has fundamentally changed the way humans communicate with each other. Cryptography’s impact and sophistication continues to adapt, and there are now numerous subfields of cryptography with boundless opportunities. Unfortunately, the Lehigh computer science curriculum doesn't expose its students to the fundamentals of cryptography. 

The mission of this club is to expose students to the fundamentals of cryptography in the hopes it might spark an interest in a field to which they otherwise may not have been exposed. In addition, we aim to connect students who share an interest in data encryption, code cracking, the privacy/security concerns of advancements in cryptography, and various other aspects of cryptography. LUCC hopes to explore these topics and create excitement and energy in a field that is often viewed as dull and daunting. Through presentations from industry experts and student connoisseurs, data security workshops, and hackathons, the LUCC hope to inspire the next generation of cryptography experts.

      Lehigh University EMS is dispatched by the University Police Department and provides emergency medical care to the Lehigh community 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. We are the crucial link between the City of Bethlehem EMS and the Lehigh Community. While the City of Bethlehem EMS averages a response time of 15 to 20 minutes, Lehigh EMS is usually on scene initiating patient care within 2-3 minutes. We provide the fundamentals of basic life support during the first crucial minutes of any emergency. Lehigh EMS is a completely volunteer student organization comprised of both PA state-certified EMT-B's and non-EMTs, and is overseen by the University Police Department.

Without this organization, there would more than likely be many more situations on campus that become unnecessarily serious because response times to provide proper intervention would be severely increased.

The Lehigh University Management Club is a student-run organization, committed to providing opportunities for students to develop management skills and reinforcing the criticality of those skills across all career functions. Through programming devoted to networking and professional development, the Management Club will provide the opportunity for students to hone skills spanning leadership, communication and people management. LU Philharmonic Orchestra

The highly acclaimed Lehigh University Philharmonic is a group of talented musicians who perform regularly at their home in Zoellner Arts Center as well as having traveled to various international venues in Europe, Asia, South America, and Africa.  Since its inception in 1993, the program has grown tremendously, with the involvement of students from all four of Lehigh's colleges, Lehigh faculty and staff, high school students, community members, and professional musicians.   

 

The central mission of the Lehigh University Orchestra Program is to provide a meaningful and unique musical experience of the highest caliber to its members and our audiences. The hallmarks of the orchestra’s successes have been its unique programming style, innovative pedagogical approach, critically acclaimed performances, and international tours.  As a result, members, as part of their educational experience at Lehigh, develop the necessary skills to succeed in life while simultaneously acquiring a deep appreciation for music and lifelong commitment to the arts.

 

The Philharmonic has recently begun reaching out to the local community by offering their time to the Bethlehem School District to teach free private lessons.  Also, the orchestra has sponsored panel discussions and pre-concert lectures involving other Lehigh faculty, students and guest artists.

 

In order to join the orchestra, an audition for the director and manager is required for both string and wind players.  Auditions occur during freshmen orientation or appointments can be made with Music Director Eugene Albulescu and Manager Linda Ganus at a later date.  Any questions can be emailed to the President, Max Watkins mbw215@lehigh.edu.

The Pre-Vet Club seeks to educate students about the requirements of veterinary school, prepare students for the rigors of veterinary school, and guide students in applying to veterinary school. The club educates and assists students through hands-on experience, and provides opportunities to shadow veterinarians, watch demonstrations, attend lectures from host speakers, and volunteer at local rescues. The club meets once a month, as the majority of time spent learning is through hands-on experience outside of regular meetings. Joining the Pre-Vet Club is a great way to obtain hours with both large and small animals, and hear of peers' experiences pre-vet students.
The Spikeball Club will give students of all skill levels an opportunity to play Spikeball. We will meet once a week to have fun and allow people to improve their skills.

The Lehigh University Steel Bridge Team is a student run organization that is sponsored by the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), as well as the American Institute of Steel Construction (AISC). The LU Steel Bridge Team applies real-world engineering as well as various technical procedures to ultimately create a steel bridge that maximizes efficiency. This team’s main goal is to take a student’s engineering capabilities, such as academia, intellect, and diligence, and refine them in order to create an experience that is competitive, goal-oriented, and most importantly, fun.

The LU Steel Bridge Team’s alternate ambition is to take home the National Student Steel Bridge Championship (NSSBC), which is held at a different college or university every year. First and foremost, competing and winning at the Mid-Atlantic ASCE conference is top priority. In order to win and perform well, every team must abide by, as well as efficiently maximize, the NSSBC specified categories. Construction economy, construction speed, lightness, aesthetics, and maximum deflection due to vertical and lateral load testing are some of the components that are judged and necessary for optimum scoring. The top three scores out of the twelve or so schools who place at regionals receive an invitation to compete at the National Championships, which consists of about 40 colleges and universities across the country.

A 40 page Student Steel Bridge Handbook is issued in August during each competing academic year, where rules to creating the steel bridge are thoroughly explained and must be strictly adhered to. Any violation to these rules will result in penalties and/or disqualification during the competition.

Comprised of two main phases, The LU Steel Bridge Team works throughout the entire academic year designing (first phase) and constructing (second phase) a scaled model of a steel bridge. Computer programming, designing, engineering computation, as well as construction accounting are a few of the areas ventured upon during the design phase. Fabrication, grinding, welding, and drilling are some of the skills used during the construction phase.

Specifically, the LU EMS plans on holding weekly sessions in a recording studio setting. Students will initially learn and apply the fundamental skills of disc jockeying and the use of digital audio equipment. After the foundation in DJing is built, students will then learn the skills of digital music production on Ableton Live. Music production sessions will be collaborative and will foster a creative environment for students. The hope is that students will reach performance skill level, and ultimately perform live. We are sponsored by the Dean of Students and function through the Student Activities Office in the Ulrich Student Center. LU's Finest Step Team is a dance club that uses the body as an instrument to make music. The rhythmic beats produced by stomping our feet, clapping our hands, and occasionally incorporating some vocals is a tradition that has been passed down through generations of people that originated from Africa. Step dancing is based on a traditional form of boot dancing but now has a modern dance twist that has been placed on it.We step and dance to regular music as well. 

 
Most importantly, we enjoy what we do. Our club brings people of different races, backgrounds, and nationalities together to perform and have fun. We pride our club in diversity and a multitude of talents which we try to utilize as much as we can. We're a club that's about stepping perfection and performing to expose people to this unique art form. Our club is not only fun but it leaves you with friends for a lifetime.

The Marching 97 performs a new student-written show during halftime at every home game, as well as one select official away game, using the Big 10 high-step marching technique. The band also plays during the game to encourage both the team and the fans, especially when we beat the Socks off of Lafayette. The Marching 97 is run by an executive committee of thirteen students who are advised by Dr. Darin Lewis, Director of the Marching 97, and Dr. David Diggs, Director of Bands.

Visit our YouTube page to see the band on the field, or follow us on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram for updates throughout the year!

By becoming a member, you gain access to a vast body of marketing knowledge, high-quality training programs, the latest tools and tactics, exposure to leading-edge thinking, and opportunities to interact with marketing peers around the world.

MAA is open to all students regardless of major. As MAA will encompass a wide spectrum of disciplines including healthcare, technology, anthropology, sociology, and other subjects, it aims to provide a platform for all students interested in multidisciplinary perspectives on medical anthropology and related areas. Ultimately, we envision to create an environment for connection and innovation, bringing positive impacts for advancement in the field of medical anthropology.

Mu Sigma Upsilon Sorority, Incorporated is the FIRST multicultural Greek-letter organization in the nation founded on November 21, 1981 at Rutgers University. Its purpose is to unite all women from all different nationalities and share with them the theme of "Mujeres Siempre Unidas" or "Women Always United". MSU was founded by five women determined to establish an organization that brought together not just women of the same background, but all women. It was their limitless vision that enabled these determined women to break down barriers and build the bridges that connected women from all different parts of the world.

 

As Lehigh University celebrates their 40th anniversary of women in Spring 2012, they welcome a group of hardworking and diverse women to their campus. Mu Sigma Upsilon Sorority, Inc. and the ladies responsible for establishing the new chapter of MSU at Lehigh seek to foster unity amongst all women, academic excellence and service to the university and community - the three goals on which Mu Sigma Upsilon Sorority, Inc. thrives upon. With limited options at Lehigh, these women thought it necessary not only for themselves but for Lehigh University to bring something different to the campus and found a chapter of Mu Sigma Upsilon Sorority, Inc.

In support of the mission of Lehigh University, the Multicultural Greek Council (MGC) serves to coordinate the activities of its member chapters, promote involvement in Greek Life, and enhance cultural awareness through the ideals, principles, history, and traditions of its respective organizations. The MGC at Lehigh University serves as a governing body that seeks to maintain high standards in the life of culturally-based fraternities and sororities by addressing, coordinating and developing strategic programming. The MGC also seeks to promote higher education, provide community service opportunities, enhance leadership abilities, and maintain the importance of scholarship among the council’s members.

Four chapters constitute the active member organizations of the MGC: Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc.; Lamba Sigma Upsilon Latino Fraternity, Inc.; Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Inc.; Mu Sigma Upsilon Latin Sorority, Inc.; and Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc.

This club has been formed because the dedicated officers behind it have seen that the campus has a need. Most organizations attempt to bring together students that share a common interest, such as painting or photography. Our club, however, seeks not to unite just those that have something particular in common, but rather to unite everyone. It is our conviction that we can make the social setting at Lehigh an atmosphere where every single person--be he or she young, old, talkative, reserved, exuberant, contained -- can live in an environment that they can comfortably and happily call their home. We plan to do this by having weekly club meetings in which members get to engage in fun activities that encourage collaboration with other students. Not only will these meetings give members soemthing fun to do, but they will also foster the building of friendships. No Lost Generation Lehigh is a student group tasked by the United States Department of State to support those affected by the ongoing Syrian refugee crisis and ensure that this generation of displaced Syrians is not lost. Our current objectives include raising awareness on campus about the refugee crisis.

In conjunction with the State Department, NLG-Lehigh hopes to serve as a model for future collaborations between the US government and university students across the country. By combining the network power of university students with the resources and expertise of the State Department, we hope to connect students with opportunities to support humanitarian efforts working to ensure a generation of Syrians is not deprived of the universal right to education.

The Office of the First-Year Experience (OFYE) is here to provide you with resources and support to make your transition to Lehigh a successful one.

Welcome to the Office of Multicultural Affairs! Whether you find our office to be your home away from home; a safe space; an area to broaden your horizons; a place to host a program or event; a study area;  a place for you to discuss issues on campus; or merely a place to rest and have a bite to eat in between classes, we welcome you to explore, share, learn and be challenged.

Multiculturalism, broadly defined, is the idea that "several different cultures can coexist peacefully and equitably" (WordNet, Princeton University, 2006). At Lehigh, multiculturalism is about recognizing, accepting and celebrating differences within our campus and surrounding communities. The Office of Multicultural Affairs at Lehigh (OMA) believes that by providing a space for students to explore their multiple identities and learn about the backgrounds and experiences of others, we can all create a culture of inclusion and equity here on campus and beyond.

We offer a range of programs,discussions, social events, resources, guest lectures and events to get you started down the path of self-discovery. If you've already started these processes, OMA programs and services can offer ways to increase your knowledge, enhance your skills and deepen your appreciation for diversity.

We are here to help you celebrate your unique contributions to this wonderfully complex society, while recognizing equal value in the contributions of others. Perhaps most importantly, we challenge you to think critically and become leaders in resolving the world's toughest issues related to diversity.

I invite you to become an active member of Lehigh's multicultural family. Let's grow together and be true agents of change!

Lehigh University Office of Residence Life

Mission Statement

The Office of Residence Life's mission is to foster a safe and inclusive learning-focused community that complements the academic mission of the University and partners with students on their personal, professional, and civic development.

To accomplish this mission, our department provides a live-in, professional Assistant Director (AD), who oversees each residential area. The Assistant Directors supervise the Gryphons who live in the residence halls. The Gryphons serve as a resource and peer leader to students, and they coordinate programs and activities that support student learning. The Gryphons serve on a rotating duty schedule and are available to students in the evenings and on weekends.

The Office of Residence Life can also serve as your liaison to other resources on campus, and we are eager to assist you in any way we can.

Visit our webpage at http://go.lehigh.edu/reslife!

Living in a residence hall is one of the most important elements of being a college student, and we try to make the experience as interesting and enjoyable as possible. At Lehigh, a residence hall is not simply a "dorm." Instead, it is a place to make new friends, study, relax, socialize, sleep, and attend interesting and educational programs. Primarily, a residence hall is a place to call home during your four years at Lehigh. All residence halls are close to the classrooms, the dining halls, the fitness center/gymnasium and the libraries, so it's a quick walk to the services and resources that Lehigh provides.

All of Lehigh's first-year residential options provide a safe, well-maintained homelike space to live, study, and learn from other residents. A variety of lifestyle options are available for upper class. If you're excited about apartment living, Lehigh offers three fantastic complexes: Campus Square, Sayre Park Village, and Trembley Park. The Warren Square complex offers theme housing opportunities for a unique living experience. Each residence hall has special features, so read each description carefully to see all of the residential choices Lehigh has to offer.

Lehigh's residence halls are staffed and run by talented and supportive people who can help you with any problem you might face at any time of the day or night. Our staff is committed to encouraging personal growth through educational programming and advising. They are there to help make your experience in the residence hall a rewarding one.

We hope you find that Lehigh feels like home, no matter which residence option you choose.

Good Luck - we think you'll like it here!

Ozzie Breiner
Director, Residential Services

Omega Psi Phi (ΩΨΦ) is a fraternity and is the first African-American national fraternal organization to be founded at a historically black college. Omega Psi Phi was founded on November 17, 1911, at Howard University in Washington, D.C. 

 The fraternity has worked to build a strong and effective force of men dedicated to its Cardinal Principles of manhood, scholarship, perseverance, and uplift. In 1927, at the urging of fraternity member Carter G. Woodson, the fraternity made National Negro Achievement Week an annual observance and it continues today as Black History Month.

Motto- " Friendship is Essential to the Soul"

Colors- Royal Purple and Old Gold

Leadership Certificate Course

The PEER Leadership Experience!

The PEER Leadership Class is designed to enhance your leadership skills, and help you understand the importance of role modeling while focusing on values, leadership styles, self awareness, mentoring, communication, student development, and feedback. All these aspects will help you be a successful leader in the Lehigh Community, and your sponsoring office or organization will greatly benefit by everything you personally learn through this opportunity and can translate to your leadership role.

 

Lehigh Collaborations

A variety of Lehigh departments have come together to create the PEER Leadership Experience to help emerging and invested leaders from across the campus connect to each other around the shared common goal of leadership development. The collaborative partners in this integrated approach to student leadership development are:

  • The Office of Student Leadership Development
  • Career Services
  • Campus Involvement & Leadership
  • The Dean of Students Advocacy & Equity Unit
  • The Office of Student Activities
  • The Alumni Association
  • Office of the First Year Experience
  • Office of Fraternity & Sorority Affairs
  • Support for Students with Disabilities
  • The Office of Residence Life
  • Athletics Leadership Development

 

 

Course Objectives:

The course is designed to provide opportunities for self exploration and personal leadership development so it has significant value for participants taking on a variety of leadership roles.  Students will build a personal foundation that will accentuate their learning in future leadership trainings.  The course will also provide students the self confidence and leadership development knowledge necessary to seek out additional opportunities on and off campus.

 

Learning Outcomes:

1.Students will be able to identify key leadership attributes that influence self awareness as a result of participating in self-reflective exercises and discussions.

2. Students will be able to point out how key concepts of student development theory and role modeling are central to the role of a leader as a result of participating in readings, self-reflective exercises, and discussions.

3. Students will be able to critically examine their personal and leadership development in the context of developmental theory as a result of personal interviews and writing a leadership development paper.

4. Students will be able to compose a leadership statement of purpose as a culmination of the P.E.E.R Leadership experience.

Our purpose is to bring together some of the brightest and most motivated students on campus and work together in a spirit of excellence to encourage three ideals:

What is a Ropes Course?

A ropes course is a series of outdoor elements made up of trees, wires, poles, and other equipment designed to create unique and challenging problem solving scenarios. Teams work together to negotiate the elements and successfully meet the challenges presented. Intential learning focused on concepts such as team dynamics, effective communication, decision making, and leadership are woven into discussions following the completion of each element. Ultimately, ropes courses are a dynamic and fun training tool, designed to help individuals and teams maximize their leadership potential.

 

The Ropes Course at Lehigh University:

Lehigh's low ropes course is located at our Mountain Top campus. The course has been newly renovated and new training material has been developed to better meet the needs of participants. The course is staffed by professionally certified ropes trainers and student peer facilitators. All of these individuals are willing and ready to help you make the most of your ropes course experience.

 

Lehigh Ropes Course Philosophy:

The Lehigh University Ropes Course is committed to a core philosophy that promotes self-knowledge and leadership competence. Our teachings are based in the Relational Leadership Model in which values-based leadership is viewed as a process, rather than a position. We promote inclusiveness and seek to engage individuals in empowering, ethical, and purposeful skill building opportunities. Learning happens by “making meaning” of life experiences. It is essential that our trainings provide individuals with significant educational experiences from which important leadership lessons are learned at the individual, group and community levels.

 

Benefits of a Ropes Course Experience:

  • Enhances group cooperation, teamwork, and leadership skills
  • Promotes problem solving and critical thinking abilities
  • Builds confidence and self esteem
  • Develops camaraderie and friendship
  • Provides a fun and challenging learning environment

Sigma Phi Epsilon was founded at Richmond College, now the University of Richmond, on November 1, 1901, on the Cardinal Principles: Virtue, Diligence, and Brotherly Love. Today, the Fraternity has grown to more than 262,000 lifetime members, including 13,500 undergraduates on 260 campuses in the United States. SigEp is currently the largest fraternity in terms of undergraduate enrollment.

 

Our mission statement is “Building Balanced Leaders for the World’s Communities.”

 

 

The Pennsylvania Epsilon Chapter of Sigma Phi Epsilon was founded at Lehigh University on September 17, 1907.  The original house was located on 704 Dakota Street in Bethlehem, PA and later moved to 61 W. Market Street, Bethlehem, PA.  In 1963, the SigEp moved into a house built for them on the Lehigh Campus in Sayre Park (commonly referred to as “The Hill”).

In 1991, Pennsylvania Epsilon had it’s charter revoked by the national fraternity, not due to any particular incident, but instead for a general decline in chapter standards.  SigEp re-colonized at Lehigh in 1994, moved back into their house on “The Hill” in 1995 and was re-charted on November 16, 1996 as a Balanced Man Chapter.  The chapter celebrated it’s centennial anniversary at Lehigh University  with a Gala Celebration to benefit SigEp’s national charity YouthAids on September 29, 2007.

 

Lehigh’s SigEp stands out and strives to be the best because all of our brothers live up to our house vision. Our brothers are defined by our commitment to academic success, personal achievement, community involvement, and fraternal endeavors. Sigma Phi Epsilon is a place where good men enter and better men leave.

As a member of the United States Collegiate Ski and Snowboard Association, the Ski Club is one of the most active athletic clubs at Lehigh during their season. Racing on both Saturday and Sunday of every weekend from early January until mid-March, the ski team requires a great commitment and is not meant for beginners.

In addition to the races, the team practices twice a week at Camelback. The races, however, occur throughout ski mountains in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania and usually feature such rivals as Lafayette, Columbia, Rutgers and Princeton, among others.

Throughout their storied history—which spans more than a decade—the Lehigh skiers—both men and women—have been utterly dominant. The men have claimed the conference championship in each of the last eight seasons and have competed in the national championship competition for the last two years, marking the first two times in Lehigh history that such a feat was accomplished.

The women’s side has been almost as impressive. Prior to 2004, the women’s team had never raced at the regionals—until they spouted off three consecutive seasons in which they qualified.

The ski team remains one of the few teams that does not cut anyone. “Anyone who has had some type of skiing experience is welcome to join us,” said team president Greg Brentrup. “We have all abilities, from really experienced racers to people who have never raced. But we are all able to train together, help each other…and have a lot of fun doing it.”

Another differentiation of the ski team from other clubs at Lehigh is the length of their season—only 6 weeks long. “I also don't think that too many club sports teams at Lehigh have competed on a national level,” said Brentrup. “So that is really exciting for us as a team and definitely a point of pride…Being able to travel to Colorado to compete last year [in Nationals] was an incredible experience.”

The ski team maintains its high level of competition and tradition year after year with a carefully designed hierarchy. As there is no coach, the team is run strictly by elected officers. Of the four officer position, Brentrup says, “Our president is almost always a senior, but we often have sophomores and juniors filling our other three officer positions. We like to have one new sophomore officer each year so that they can have two seasons as an officer before taking over as the probable president in their senior year.”

As displayed by their stellar achievements and bright future, the ski team clearly has a polished and working system in place.
