The Student Senate is a body of students who act as representatives in voicing the concerns of the undergraduate community at Lehigh University.
 
The Senate is comprised of 55 Members from all of the university’s living groups: Fraternities, Sororities, On-Campus, Off-Campus, Athletes, and First-Year students. Each constituency has nine seats except for athletes which has 5 seats per semester. 

The Senate is divided into a number of different sub-groups. There are three standing committees: Student Outreach, Allocations, and Club Affairs. Student Outreach’s task is to advertise and promote Senate and its activities. Allocations is responsible for allocating the Senate’s funds to the many different recognized clubs around campus. Club Affairs is responsible for providing services and resources to ensure these clubs succeed.
 
In the beginning of each academic year, the full Senate also recognizes CLIP committees. These committees are organized for the entirety of the school year and have specific goals. 

 
Senate also has the power to create ad-hoc committees to deal with temporary issues as they arise throughout the year. Ad-Hoc committees can be formed and disbanded on an as-needed basis.
 
The Senate Executive Board is responsible for managing and directing all of these groups and the Senate as a whole in completing its mission. The Executive Board consists of the President, Vice-President, Treasurer, Secretary, and Parliamentarian.

The Greek Emerging Leaders Program                                            

 

 

The GEM Experience-for new members:

 

Thirty-five new members are selected each Spring semester to be a part of the GEM leadership experience.  Participants receive mentoring from juniors and seniors in the Greek community and engage in 6 training sessions and an overnight retreat.  As a result of this experience, sophomore leaders:

 

-Meet and network with emerging leaders from Greek chapters

-Receive face time with faculty and staff members from across the Lehigh campus

-Understand the importance of building and growing relationships as the foundation of leadership

-Learn how to manage small and large groups in order to simultaneously achieve personal and organizational goals

 

Applications are available each March and the application process concludes in early April.  If you are a new member, we hope that you will consider being a part of the GEM Experience.

 

The GEM Experience-for Upperclassmen

 

Being a GEM Mentor allows juniors and seniors to positively engage the newest leaders in the Greek community.  The mentors help them shape the future of Greek life at Lehigh by:

 

-Planning and facilitating the major components of the GEM Leaders Program

-Marketing and recruiting new members and mentors

-Planning social activities and service opportunities

 

As a result of their mentor experience, these upperclassmen develop essential facilitation, communication and public speaking skills.  To get involved as a GEM mentor, learn more by visiting the Greek Emerging Leaders Program website.

This is an organization founded on the idea that happiness is infectious and that this campus can be changed through the influx of positive energy. We aspires to affect the students on a personal level by bringing small moment of happiness to them during their daily routines and times of stress. The hope is that these small moments may build upon each other to help create a happier and more positive Lehigh Community.

The Helius Dance Club aims to form a small-sized professional dance team of international students and a bigger dance community of non-professional dancers who have the same passion for dance. Helius is the God of Sun in Greek mythology. It is a metaphor to describe the power of dance and it brings us strength and joy. The Helius Dance Club mainly focus on hip-hop and we are working to combine American hip-hop and Asian hip-hop to create a new form of dance with more energy.

The Hobo Army improv comedy club was founded in 2005 (or 2006) at Lehigh by a group of students looking to build their improv skills and create new opportunities for student involvement that were different than the average club. We strive to promote teamwork, individuality, and creativity in our group sessions, but we do so in a friendly, welcoming environment where anyone is welcome to come out and try out improv comedy with us and learn more about the craft. We have performed in the Lehigh Valley at Godfrey Daniel's and at the Lehigh Steel Stacks comedy festivals on numerous occasions, alongside members of local improv troupes such as The Associated Mess, Mandudebro, and the Flighty Ducks. We look to continue to grow as a group and expand our operation to not only the Lehigh University community, but the Lehigh Valley as well.

column4: The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) is an organization dedicated to the advancement of members in education and employment through professional development, diversity, and service. SASE seeks to prepare members for success in the global business world, explore and encourage cultural diversity in the workplace and on campus, and provide opportunities for members to make contributions to the local community. By taking advantage of workshops, panels, meetings and conferences, members are given opportunities to network with companies, professionals and other SASE members while learning skills useful to all walks of life.
column5: The Lehigh Chapter of the Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers

column4: The Healthy & Happy Living Club's purpose is to create a campus founded on the ideals of wellness, internally and externally. Some of the events that we host include destressing fun activities like yoga, meditation, watching funny movies, as well as philanthropy and volunteer events.  As an organization, we promote the importance of living life to the fullest and obtaining a healthy lifestyle mentally and physically.  We typically meet on Mondays in STEPS though our locations and times may change.  To learn more information and to follow for events, like our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/LUHealthyHappy/.

column4: The Astronomy Club will focus on the Lehigh community interest with science and space. The club's main focus are topics in astronomy. It will aim at providing those on campus with an opportunity to learn more about astronomy as well as experience some hands on techiniques in knowing our night sky. For example, we will be taking a closer look with telescopes at the objects that revolve around us.

This club's goal is to learn about engineering fundamentals behind building geowalls. We will build several geowalls throughout the year, refining our technique and efficiency, in the hopes of competing against other schools.

column4: The Middle Eastern Student Union aims to represent the Middle Eastern culture on campus by allowing students to show their pride in this heritage. The club will include all students that are interested in expanding their knowledge on the Arab World and who are willing to be apart of this diverse culture. Not only would this club include Middle Eastern students, but other students who enjoying exploring and learning more about the Arab World.

We are a young but rapidly growing and ambitious organization that cooperates with Lehigh After Dark and other campus organizations to bring to campus the best live music atmosphere possible.  

The Music Box's goals are described as follows:

1. To act as a gathering place and network for Lehigh musicians where they can form bands, learn from each other's talents, and appreciate their different styles of playing and musical interstest.

2. To provide student musicians with rehearsal space and gear (drum set, P.A. system, amps, mics, etc.) that are not provided by Lehigh.

3. To organize and host events that allow student musicians to showcase their talents and gain experience with live performance. We currently host monthly open mic nights, the Lehigh Battle of the Bands series, acoustic showcases on the front lawn, and charity concerts such as the Frattle of the Bands. 

4. To hold a database and connections with professional musicians, managers, venues, studios, labels, booking agents, and other experts within the music industry to provide student bands and musicians with opportunities to perform and network outside of the Lehigh community. We promote ambitious goals while providing the resources necessary to achieve those goals. 

In addition to this, we will also host musician's workshops as well as supply all other organizations on campus with our repertoire of musical acts to provide live music entertainment when needed. This means that solo musicians and musical groups joining our organization will obtain guaranteed experience in performing in front of a wide array of diverse audiences.

The National Society of Collegiate Scholars (NSCS) is an honors organization that recognizes and elevates high achievers. NSCS provides career and graduate school connections, leadership and service opportunities and offers nearly half a million dollars in scholarships annually. NSCS members are deeply committed to scholarship, leadership and service and as a result, are impacting their campus and local communities every day.

http://www.nscs.org/chapters/lehigh-university/
column5: The National Society of Collegiate Scholars

Transportation & Parking Services is comprised of four bus services, car rentals, vehicle garages, a gas station and parking services on the three Lehigh campuses. There are 4,050 total parking spots on the Asa Packer and Goodman Campuses.  Transportation office is on Goodman Campus and the Parking office is on Asa Packer Campus in Johnson Hall.

Transportation & Parking Services strives to apply technology to simplify the ease of parking and transportation and uses SMARTcard and SMARTmeter technology, as well as bus GPS and a tracking website.

The primary objective of the organization is to promote the support between Turkish students, scholars and staff at Lehigh University and their families while representing Turkey and its diverse culture. TSA organizes cultural, sport and recreational activities in line with its primary objective mentioned in the purpose. It participates to the similar activities organized by other organizations at Lehigh University. TSA helps undergraduate new students and scholars to be acquainted with the local environment.

Turning Point USA is an American conservative or right wing 501(C)(3) nonprofit organization founded on June 5, 2012, by Wheeling, Illinois high school graduate Charlie Kirk. The organization states its mission is to "identify, educate, train, and organize students to promote fiscal responsibility, free markets and limited government." Turning Point USA has more than 1,000 chapters in colleges and high schools and has registered thousands of voters since 2012.
column5: Turning Point USA at Lehigh University

column4:
University Productions (UP) is Lehigh University’s student run entertaintment and social programing board. UP formulates, supervises, and funds large scale undergraduate social activities to provide an increased array of social options for University students.

Arts & Excursions | Comedy | Music |  Special Events.

Why Join UP?

Short Term Perks

  • Back stage passes to all the events
  • Decision in who performs at Lehigh
  • Join an extremely productive organization
  • Resume Builder
  • Lots of give-a-ways: t-shirts, sunglasses, etc

Long Term Perks

  • Real leadership experience
  • Real experience working with a budget
  • Real planning experience
  • Networking

UP is organized into an Executive Board, five Programing Committees, and is advised by the Director of Student Activities. Each committee has two Directors that guide their committee. Since we are student run, any and all students have input and can help to put on events.

Arts & Excursions: If it is off-campus then A&E runs it, from going to sporting events in New York and Philadelphia to Broadway Shows. Join and you have the ability to lead a trip. 

Comedy: Selects the comedians that come to campus. The committee plans roughly three large shows, a Kick Off Fall Semester Show, Family Weekend Show, and Final Show in the spring in addition to a smaller comedy series. Comedians who performed at campus include Daniel Tosh, Rob Riggle, and Louis CK.

Music: Focuses on both large scale concerts in the fall and spring. Concerts involve Lehigh-Laf-apalooza and QUEST that have hosted artists such as Big Sean, Flosstradamus, Wiz Khalifa, The Roots, Ben Folds, Gym Class Heroes, Cake, and Boys Like Girls. 

Special Events: From holiday themed parties to talent shows, Special Events plans everything else that UP's other committees do not. With Special Events the possibility for events at Lehigh are endless. Some events have included: Oktoberfest, Midnight Munchies and SpringFest.

Marketing: Our marketing team helps in advertising UP as an organization and our great events. If you have graphic design experience or just want to help in getting the word out about UP, definitely sign up. 

We are always looking for students to join our team!

If you have ever been interested in learning about video -- both the shooting and the production...or, if you have a background in video and would like to do more, not only can you be involved with the activities of this, Lehigh's 'official' video club; you will be hired to go out and shoot various on-campus events (and make $$$!)

Past officers of this club have gone on to work professionally...so this is great training!

If interested, please contact Allyson Abramson, President:  ana319.

A map, a video camera, some cash to spend in the hottest tourist destination in the United States and time to explore with a group of your new best friends. What do all of these have in common? Urban Ops: NYC and you!!

 

Urban Ops is a an exciting prelusion program for first-year students that provides students with a jumpstart on their Lehigh journey. Throughout the experience, students will participate in a ropes course, complete a scavenger hunt throughout New York City, meet young Lehigh alumni and learn concepts of group dynamics that will help them navigate the plethora of involvement opportunities Lehigh has to offer. After successfully completing a basic training on campus, they will become a member of Lehigh’s covert Special Forces known as Urban Operations and start the mission...

USAEE Lehigh is a student chapter of USAEE, a national forum founded to facilitate the exchange of ideas and issues among professionals interested in energy economics. USAEE is the largest affiliate of the International Association of Energy Economics. It is comprised of local and regional chapters which hold multiple national conferences every year.

The goal of our club is to host symposiums each semester surrounding issues in the energy industry. We highlight developments in the energy industry, both renewable and non. In bringing speakers to campus and holding monthly meetings, we touch on the multi-faceted energy industry, addressing the overlap between technology, economics, and policy.

Lehigh University Veg Club aims to promote reducing or living free from animal products and animal cruelty. It is open to anyone, whether they be vegan, vegetarian, plant-based, or simply interested in learning more about the lifestyle.

Volunteer Experience is a pre-orientation program with the goal of introducing our first year students to Lehigh University's campus and the surrounding area through community service.

For the three days of the Volunteer Experience, students are immersed in a rewarding service project and lend a helping hand to the local community while meeting and bonding with other incoming first year students.

The Wind Ensemble at Lehigh University is a select group of students dedicated to the performance of original music written for woodwinds, brass and percussion. Drawn from various colleges of the University, these students represent many diverse majors including engineering, business, as well as many fields of the liberal arts. Under Mr. Digg's direction, the Wind Ensemble was honored by Downbeat magazine, receiving the award for the most outstanding college symphonic band in its 22nd Annual Student Music Awards.
WLVR is Lehigh University's student run radio station.   WLVR is a free form radio station broadcasting 24 hours a day at 91.3FM in the Lehigh Valley and streaming online at wlvr.org.

Lehigh University's Women in Business  is an organization that seeks to promote our members' personal and professional development by engaging them in activities and workshops that support business skills and etiquette.

The Lehigh University chapter of the national organization Women in Computer Science is a club established to encourage and support female involvement in computer related majors. As an organization, we hope to foster a sense of community, friendship, and strength among females in STEM fields. We believe that bringing all of the Women in Computer Science together for social and technical events will make them more confident and comfortable in and out of the classroom and will guide them through their Lehigh experience and the rest of their careers.
